newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks end mixed in slipping turnover.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks end mixed in slipping turnover.

text.p: Taiwan stocks closed mixed in narrow Friday trading as some investors took quick profits against the market's two-day rebound. Brokers said they expected the index slowly to test strong resistance at 8,250 points .
The index finished a scant 6.28 points or 0.08 percent lower at 8,144.38, back from an intra-day 8,192.91 high. Turnover was a slack T$77.7 billion, compared with Thursday's T$90 billion.
"Profit-taking pressure gets heavier as the index approaches 8,200 points," said National Securities fund manager Allen Huang. "Investors' confidence has improved but people are not bullish."
Brokers said 8,250 points stood as strong technical and psychological resistance in the near term.
"It looks like the market needs a longer consolidation period," Huang said.
The late morning announcement of an unexpectedly low 2.59 percent unemployment rate in April had no immediate impact on the market, brokers said.
Financial shares were weak, falling 0.81 percent.
Two bank shares that transferred directly to Taiwan's main stock exchange from the fledgling over-the-counter market fell sharply as profit-taking soured their debut, brokers said.
Newcomer Dah Ah Bank 2829.TW plunged T$1.9 or 5.09 percent to T$35.4, while Grand Commercial Bank was down T$1.7 or 4.57 percent to T$35.5.
Banking stocks likely would attract less interest from investors compared with strong but volatile electronic shares.
"Unlike banking and other sectors, electronics' upside potential is unlimited," Huang said.
Albert Lin, research head of Golden Securities, said: "Only electronics can lead the market's uptrend."
The whole electronic index rose 0.73 percent.
